 This just so happens to be a topic that is currently one of primary research interests as a criminologist. Our criminal justice system has a history of focusing on one group of offenders over a particular period of time. This practice is simply part of the "get tough on crime" movement that was initially developed during the late 1970s and early 1980s; however, the Reagan administration is widely associated with its onset. During the 1980s, our CJ system was focused on drug offenders; hence the "War on Drugs." During the early 1990s, our system began focusing more on juvenile violent offenders. More recently, sex offenders and terrorists (the "War on Terrorism") have become the primary targets. Sex offender registries do some good, I'll give them credit. There are some offenders who are very sick individuals and we need to keep our children away from them. In contrary, there are many more offenders who do not pose significant threats to the rest of society, but they still are placed on registries.
 
 Since its onset, the "get tough" movement has not had a huge impact on deterring crime or reducing recidivism. For the most part, registries simply net widen a system that is already overwhelmed with offenders. Policing sex offenders appears like it's reducing crime and preventing further sexual abuse cases. However, in looking at the big picture, which is difficult for a lot of policy makers to do, it's simply a fad and not serving as a valuable purpose in reducing crime.
 
 In my opinion, if we really wanted to adequately address sex offenders and sexual abuse in general, we must focus on prevention, treatment, and education. Educate your children at very young ages about "good touch" and "bad touch." Don't be afraid to talk with them about the natural aspects of sex and sexual behaviors. We should also effectively treat sexual abuse victims and offenders. Recent research has shown that sexual offender treatment can work to reduce recidivism if delivered well and appropriately. As a former counselor, I have seen its good effects.
 
 Let me get off of my soap box here, but ultimately, we must rely more on informal social control rather than the police and the justice system to rescue us. We must strengthen our families and communities in order to truly prevent and reduce crime.
Zardoz
